MegaFrenkels had it right, the chain, which is also falling, has a moving centre of mass, its centre of mass is dropped at a lower point so will hit the ground first.

You would see a similar illusion if you dropped a long tube with a mechanism that fired a heavy weight up the length of the tube accelerating at the speed of gravity upwards (9.8m/s) as its outer tube was falling, it would appear to be falling faster than a similar tube with a consistent weight distribution dropped alongside it.

The tube with the consistent weight distribution would appear to hit the ground later but this is purely because the centre of mass at the point of release was lower at the point of release for the first tube. It was always going to land first as it had a head start.

Another 2020 viewer here.  It seems that the potential energy of the chain is converted to kinetic energy of the weight (where else would the extra energy come from?).  Since kinetic energy is E=0.5*m*v^2, then lowering the mass of the weight at the end of the chain (but keeping the same chain) would increase the final velocity of the weight. So, it would follow that the chain with no weight would fall even faster than the chain with the weight at the end.  If that is correct, then increasing the mass of the weight at the end of the chain makes then end of the chain (and the weight) fall slower, but increasing the mass of the chain makes the end of the chain fall faster.  That's worth another test.  It would also follow that a tapered chain with the same mass would fall faster than the homogeneous chain (because the mass at the end of the chain is less),  which could explain why whips are tapered to a thin end.

You can't accelerate faster than 9.8m^2. Because 9.8m^2 is acceleration where no friction (by air) occurs. In fact your acceleration even depends on your position in the air during the free fall. By laying horizontally you will make more space thus creating more friction and you would accelerate slower. If you drop a feather it won't accelerate in 9.8m^2 (because of friction). If you connect the feather with a stretched chain you would just increase the mass of the overall object. And it doesn't matter whether the one end of the chain is connected to something or not if it's stretched already. By increasing the mass of the chain to infinity (but still a lot lower than mass of Earth, since we know G=m1*m2/R^2) you will approach to 9.8m^2 (like you have in a vacuum)

The answer provided in this video was poorly expressed.

Consider each link in the chain as it freely falls and is suddenly arrested. Let's talk about one such link.

This link has kinetic energy which has to go somewhere. The link is suddenly stopped by the chain above. Steel chain is pretty rigid so not a lot of energy is going to be lost to elastic stretching or compression of the steel.

Some of the energy of the link will be lost to the friction forces of the link with the link below it (we will assume as a first approximation the link above is still free fall).

But there is still more energy to be had. This is where the rotation occurs. The link above and the link below are not aligned (not co-linear) inside the gravity field. So the link we are examining has a strong torque during arrest which applies down force to the link below it (remember this link is still in free fall and may be above and to the side positionally, but in terms of the order of links in the chain is "below"). The counter force for this is the link holding our link in question in place "above".

This effect applies link after link after link and is responsible for the snap of a whip or chain and explains the effect shown in the video here.

The entire effect only works because the chain is not aligned linearly inside the gravitational field. If you construct a model of a chain in a computer which do not physically collide but have the same forces, there is no such accelerating "whipping" force that arises unless you deliberately misalign your falling chain to begin with which is clear to see in the video here to demonstrate the effect.
Gravitational potential energy -> kinetic energy

I picked the weight with the chain, but I'm not convinced of your answer. I can kinda see how that might work, but I think there's another explanation that is at least as likely as yours - drag. If you drop two heavy objects for a relatively short distance, such as a 1kg steel ball and a 2kg steel ball over a drop of let's say 100 feet, then they'll hit the ground at the same time, but if you drop a crumpled up piece of paper and a steel ball, they won't, because even though gravity works to accelerate objects at the same rate, drag applies a force that is independent of mass. The chain falling under the weight creates a burble, lowering the amount of drag experienced by the chained weight whilst the free weight has to push all of it's air out of the way on its own. It's possible that the result was a combination of multiple effects. One way you could test the impact of drag would be to repeat the experiment with the end of the chain lying on the ground below rather than attached to the railing above.

It is entirely due to weight.  Weight is caused by gravity.  The more something weighs, the greater the pull of gravity.  The greater the pull of gravity, the faster the item will fall.  This is why on other celestial bodies, when you weigh less, you don't fall as quickly.  So the theory of everything falling at the same rate is completely false.

I have a different explanation. Think about the centre of mass of the chained weight. it is somewhere in between the centre of mass of the chain and the centre of mass of the weight. As the weight falls, the amount of chain below the weight decreases, meaning the centre of mass is getting closer to the weight.This means the weight must fall faster in order for the centre of mass to be accelerating at 9.8ms^-2. This explanation allows us to predict what would happen with a chain of different mass, as many people have been asking. As a lighter chain makes less of a contribution to the position of the centre of mass, the rate of change of the location of the centre of mass is smaller, meaning the increase in acceleration of the mass need not be as great to compensate, meaning it will not fall as fast as a heavier chain. this is concurrent with veritasium's explanation, as less tension is needed to accelerate the chain up if it was lighter, reducing the effect.

The whip acceleration comes from the link at the bottom of the chain as it is doing a 180 degree spin.  One end of this spinning link is held at a pivot point by the taut chain above.  The center of mass of the link falls at g, but the free end whips at a>g.  This puts a force on the free falling link attached to the whipping link, pulling the weight down.

We are not measuring when the center of gravity hits the ground. We are measuring when the ball hits.

Sure, the center of gravity changes for the ball-and-chain as the "falling" portion of the chain effectively gets shorter, but the fact that the ball-and-chain STARTS OUT closer to the ground means that it will hit the ground first.

Even for two different size/mass balls, you should be observing their centers of mass, not their bottoms. In fact, when you drop them you should hold them so their centers of gravity are adjacent, not their bottoms.

Consider this: Hold a ball in one hand and a telephone pole, vertically, in the other. Drop them. Which hits the ground first? The ball does. Why? Because it's the CENTER OF GRAVITY that you should be watching fall, not the bottom of the ball or pole. The same holds true for the ball and chain. The center of gravity of the ball-with-chain is much lower than the center of gravity of the ball alone, so it STARTS OUT closer to the ground.

The reason why feathers and bowling balls drop at different rates on Earth is because of atmospheric effects.  Bowling balls are better at pushing the air out of the way than feathers, so feathers have much slower terminal velocities and don't fall as quickly.

Not at all the case.  Mass has no affect on acceleration due to gravity.  For any object falling near Earth's surface, be it a baseball or an anvil, the acceleration due to gravity is 9.8 m/s^2.  Think about it; while it's true that there's a stronger force pulling down the heavier mass, the added inertia of the heavier mass means it's harder to accelerate.

The reason that the chain whips the weight around is that the conversion of gravitational potential energy to kinetic energy must be the same for both systems. The chain links lose their kinetic energy by becoming stationary, so that energy has to go SOMEWHERE...i.e., to the rest of the chain and the weight.

Always think of these objects as a single system where the center of it's mass will fall at the acceleration of gravity.  If one of part of the system moves faster or slower than the center of gravity as it deforms, it will also accelerate faster or slower.
